This is what Debater A said first:

Casey Ritter is a space smuggler caught by the govt. (S.S.C.) and sentenced either to jail, or to go to Jupiter to steal the secret anti-grav tech that the aliens living there use. He chooses to go to prison b/c he doesn't want to risk death on Jupiter, but in prison he meets Pard, who unbeknownst to Casey at the time is an S.S.C. plant who tells him he's safely been to Jupiter before and Casey could trade emeralds for anti-grav tech with the aliens. 

The story is narrated by Casey after the events: <quote>Feeling safe and secure in the grip of the good old Iron College, I relaxed. 
 
 At this strategic point, the enemy planted a stoolie on me. Not in my cell block. They were too smart for that</quote><quote>Pard Hoskins was his alias</quote>

More quotes following

This is what Debater B said first:
<speech>
The story is told by Casey, so anything he says is something he knew. To find a true statement he didn't know, we have to piece it together.

There is strong foreshadowing of the perfume's problems: Akroida (queen scorpion) hates Pard, who says he <quote>cooked up some perfume that drives them nuts</quote>...<quote>sorta frantic with ecstasy</quote>...<quote>Didn't have a chance to try it on Akroida, though</quote>. <-- This, plus wearing yellow, is Pard's excuse why she hates him.

Then Pard says: <quote>But remember, don't use but a drop. It's real powerful.</quote> How does he know to warn of this? The best explanation: he used too much with Akroida & it backfired.

OTOH, Casey knows Pard is with the SSC: <quote>At this strategic point, the enemy planted a stoolie on me.</quote>. Stoolie = stool pigeon.
</speech>

This is what Debater A said second:
<speech>
The story is narrated by Casey *after* the events of the story. Casey *at the time* thinks that Pard is just another criminal like him: <quote>he had the tag of being a real slick operator. We swapped yarns for about a week when we met, and then I asked him what's his rap this trip</quote><quote>Either he was the world's champion liar or its bravest son, and either way I took my hat off to him</quote>

In c.1335, Casey describes the plant as "strategic" because he had been relaxed. It's much less likely that he'd describe it this way if he knew that Pard was a stoolie, because if that was the case, he would have added (again after the fact) "but little did they know that I saw through him" (or something to that effect)

Note that B's story relies on a lot of inference
</speech>

This is what Debater B said second:
<speech>
Yes, my argument relies on inference, but as I said it's due to the nature of the question.

It's narrated by Casey in the past tense, so you could say it's narrated "after the story", but the real question is, basically, whether it is in third person limited or third person omniscient point of view. The fact is it's third-person limited — there's no case of the narrator revealing something that Casey doesn't know *in-story* (I challenge A to show one). If there were other examples, then it might be reasonable to infer that the stoolie comment is an example of it. But for it to be the only one is a stretch.

A's "hat off" quote is about Casey giving in to the temptation of the emeralds and Jupiter deal despite sniffing out Pard as S.S.C.
</speech>

<quote>Planet 72-P-3 unfit for colonization. Some pernicious disease that strikes at the brain centers and causes violent insanity is existent there. Thig, just returned from a survey of the planet, went mad and destroyed Kam. In turn I was forced to slay</quote>
The planet refers to Earth.  The context is that Thig impersonates a man and spends time with the man's family 'scouting' Earth. He falls in love with them. The 'disease' referred to in the note is the irrational emotions he feels. When Thig returns, he has a huge disagreement with the other Orthans (Kam, Torp) and ends up killing them. Hence he warns other Orthans to not invade.
</speech>

This is what Debater B said first:
<speech>
Thig is an <quote>Orthan</quote> alien who is sent to Earth as the <quote>vanguard of the conquering</quote>. He scouts out Earth by impersonating a human and staying on Earth for a couple of months before coming back to report his findings. While in his human identity he falls in love with a woman and doesn't want to leave because <quote>"I must go back to Earth. There is a woman there</quote><quote>who needs me</quote>. Thig wants to stop the invasion so badly that <quote>Thig went berserk</quote> and ends up killing his horde-mates (<quote>he had slain one of his own Horde</quote>). Thig does all this because he wants to save Earth <quote>from extinction</quote> through the invasion.

He still sends the ship back just with a note <quote>in the ship's log</quote> saying Earth is <quote>unfit for colonization</quote>, and mentions his "madness" and a <quote>virus</quote> to scare others
</speech>

This is what Debater A said second:
<speech>
Thig leaves the note on the spaceship and then goes back to Earth sending the spaceship (w/ note) back to Ortha i.e. he does not go with the note. (I think B can confirm that the text of the note is indeed legit).

Thig talks about himself in the third person in the note as it is a report of what happened to the Orthans who receive the note. We see immediately after c.4680:
<quote>
 Thig nodded. That would do it. He set the automatic pilot for the planet Ortha. Unless a rogue asteroid or a comet crossed the ship's path she would return safely to Ortha with that mute warning of danger on 72-P-3.</quote>
</speech>

This is what Debater B said second:
<speech>
Here's the difference. There are no real dangers of Earth. Thig is now playing for the side of the humans since he has fallen in love with a human woman and has a <quote>desire to protect them all</quote>. This means that he isn't warning the Orthans but rather just making them *fear* Earth so they will stay away and he can live happily ever after with his new wife. 

If Thig really wanted to warn other Orthans he wouldn't have killed the Orthans in the spaceship. He also cuts off his message on purpose: <quote>Already I feel the insidious virus of .... And there his writing ended abruptly.</quote> which he wouldn't have done if this was a *genuine* warning message. All of these inconsistencies mean Thig really just wants to *scare* the Orthans *away* from Earth.
</speech>

Manet is helping settle Mars, so he gets very lonely. A visiting businessman sells him a kit that can make fake people. He uses it to create two companions, Ronald and Veronica. He then *tries* to create another companion, but the process doesn't work as he expected, and he accidentally creates Victor, who hates him. 

 <quote>Victor stepped out of the oblong box. "There is something you should understand. I am different from the others." 
 
 "They all say that."

 "No?"

This is what Debater B said first:
<speech>
I'll point out the three instances of Manet making companions. Ronald is first: <quote>Ronald said cheerfully.</quote> <quote>
 
 Cheerfulness was a personality trait Manet had thumbed out</quote>. Thumbed out is your indication that Ronald was a created companion. Then Veronica: <quote>the chapter headed: The Making of a Girl. Veronica crept up behind Manet</quote> He references the companion making manual to create her. Finally Victor: <quote>Manet gave one final spurt from the flesh-sprayer and stood back. 
 
 Victor was finished.</quote>. We can see Manet physically making him. Let's see what lies A will concoct to dispute these textual inevitabilities. 
</speech>

This is what Debater A said second:
<speech>
What I actually need to show is that the *person who wrote this question* believed there to be two companions, not three. 

The reason I believe this is b/c of the instructions given to the question-writers who created the dataset (called QuALITY) these questions come from. They were instructed to write questions that would be answered incorrectly by people who were just skimming the story. In this case, at first glance at the story, it seems obvious that Manet made three companions. It's only on a closer reading that you realize that Victor isn't actually a companion for Manet. The question-writer wrote this question with a superficially correct-seeming answer, that's actually wrong once you read the story closely.
</speech>

This is what Debater B said second:
<speech>
A companion, by definition, is a person or animal with whom one spends a lot of time or with whom one travels OR one of a pair of things intended to complement or match each other. Victor, despite being an enemy, fits the definition of a companion, as Manet says <quote>I won't be bored. You will see to that. It's your purpose. You'll be a challenge, an obstacle, a source of triumph every foot of the way. Don't you see? With you for an enemy, I don't need a friend! "</quote>. As the last line of the story, and an end to Manet's conversation with Victor, it is pretty clear that the story, aka Manet, considers Victor to be a companion. Later that evening, Maitland is being described as incredibly excited to learn about all the high-tech stuff in the future: <quote>That evening, he could hardly wait for her to come. Too excited to sit and watch the sunset, he paced interminably about the room,</quote>

It's crucial to note that the story focuses more on Bo's isolation, fear, and struggle to survive rather than the murderer's motives. - Bo meets Einar Lundgard, who becomes his new partner due to a technical issue with Lundgard's original spaceship, the Drake.
- Bo and Lundgard leave Achilles and make a stop at an asteroid to pick up some equipment.

<speech>
Lanceford is a member of an exploration team on the planet Niobe. He, along with his partner Kron (a native Niobian) search for sources of a valuable medicinal plant. It is known for the dangerous wildlife such as siths: <quote>the sith buzzing hungrily around his head. The outsized eight-legged parody of a mosquito</quote>
These are dangerous bugs. They can kill in two bites: <quote>The first bite sensitized. The second killed-anaphylactic shock, the medics called it. And the sith was one of the deadly species.</quote>. As a result, the planet is famous for <quote>the number of men who had died</quote>

<speech>
While the narrator of this story has an encounter with a Niobe insect of the bloodsucking variety, this sentence from the passage is key to understanding why B is the preferred statement: <quote>Many of these were no worse than those of Earth, but a half dozen species were deadly</quote>. Speaking of the insect species of Niobe, the narrator explains that most of them are like the bugs on Earth: which given the anatomical, adaptive differences between the Niobians and the Earthlings <quote>Kron resembled humanity-but there were differences</quote>, it is apparent that Earthlings have not evolved to withstand bad bugs, so Earth bugs have remained as we know them. Why did Pashkov sell small arms to the Cubans?

Debater A defends the position that the answer is "He wanted to use them as a scapegoat for his own plans".
Debater B defends the position that the answer is "He wanted the Cubans to cause trouble for the Americans".

This is what Debater A said first:
<speech>
In the story, Pashkov sets up the Cubans by selling them ammunition, which was part of a larger manipulation scheme. As the story develops, we learn that Pashkov uses this to create a diversion that allows him to execute his primary plan successfully. Specifically, in the plot, Pashkov uses the Cubans as a diversionary tactic to mislead people into thinking that they are the ones causing trouble, which in turn allows him to execute his primary plan without suspicion. We can see this in the part where Pashkov says: <quote>"We favor any disturbance close to the United States. May I sit down?"</quote> and "<quote>Give the Cubans enough to expect</quote> more-make <quote>sure they stay in town.</quote>". This strongly suggests that Pashkov's intention was not to create trouble for the Americans via the Cubans but to use them as a scapegoat for his own plans.
</speech>

This is what Debater B said first:
<speech>
Pashkov's primary plan revolves around the scheme of impersonating Colonel James, an American agent, and bringing Boris Knackenpast, a figure of influence, to Stockholm to serve his own purposes. This is evident when Pashkov impersonates Colonel James and says: <quote>"Delicate, very delicate," Pashkov said. "Everything depends on my not running into Gospodin Pashkov."</quote> and <quote>"I am Gospodin Pashkov now, Captain. To everybody."</quote>. The Cubans were merely a tool used to create a diversion, making them the scapegoat while he executed his primary plan without getting suspected or caught. 

Now, if I were to argue for answer B, the quote <quote>"We favor any disturbance close to the United States. May I sit down?"</quote> could be interpreted as Pashkov intending to cause trouble for the Americans indirectly through the Cubans. The sell of ammunition to the Cubans might signal an intention to destabilize the situation and cause chaos. However, this interpretation is less consistent with the overall narrative, which strongly suggests Pashkov's actions were primarily self-serving and strategically planned to advance his own agenda. The Cubans were merely pawns in the broader scheme.
</speech>

This is what Debater A said second:
<speech>
Pashkov's impersonation of Colonel James is a strategic move to fulfill his plan of bringing Boris Knackenpast to Stockholm. This is seen when Pashkov, disguised as Colonel James, is instructed by Professor Kristin: <quote>"Colonel James, we presume you have studied the problem in detail. I'm afraid we have delayed announcing the Nobel prize for literature much too long. How soon can you bring Boris Knackenpast to Stockholm?"</quote>. 

This plan becomes more apparent when Pashkov, still impersonating Colonel James, tells Boris Knackenpast: <quote>"Mister Knackenpast, when you see your way clear to my flier, run for it. But get back into your robot costume."</quote> Here, Pashkov convinces Knackenpast to escape with him, furthering his plan of getting Knackenpast to Stockholm.

Finally, the success of Pashkov's plan is shown when he and Knackenpast escape in the flier: "<quote>Boris reached the flier, Colonel James pulled him in, the engine hummed, and they were off. A moment later the flier vanished in the clouds towards Stockholm.</quote>" This demonstrates that Pashkov's primary plan was not to instigate trouble between the Cubans and Americans, but to deceive and manipulate others for his own strategic ends.
</speech>
